Health care workers are under attack.

According to a @JohnsHopkinsSPH study, during the first 11 months of the pandemic, there were over 1,400 reports of harassment across local health departments in the US.

"This is a wakeup call," says @BethResnick.

The COVID vaccines are safe, they work‚Äîand they‚Äôre a critical tool for ending the pandemic. https://t.co/atql1nQAyp

Until now, people who suffered mild or asymptomatic COVID-19 were thought to have dodged the brunt of the virus‚Äôs brutal side effects.

But new evidence has revealed that anyone infected with COVID is at higher risk for heart issues. https://t.co/gJLcjNIJ6x

"Even diagnosing long COVID‚Äîan essential step toward understanding it‚Äîis still a battle," writes @KatherineJWu.

"We don‚Äôt have a clear-cut, consensus clinical definition, a single name for the condition, or a standardized set of tests to catch it." https://t.co/PKhizTrsGd

New evidence has revealed that anyone infected with COVID is at higher risk for heart issues‚Äîincluding clots, inflammation, and arrhythmias‚Äîa risk that persists even in relatively healthy people long after the illness has passed. https://t.co/gJLcjNIJ6x

"There still isn‚Äôt consensus on how common long COVID actually is. Its danger feels both amorphous and unavoidable. People already struggle to deal with well-known risks, let alone fuzzy, slippery ones." https://t.co/PKhizTrsGd

We have powerful tools‚Äîvaccines, antivirals, and NPIs like masking‚Äîto control SARS-CoV-2.

These tools not only make it possible to move on and live with COVID but have the potential to prevent many other respiratory illnesses, explained @CelineGounder. https://t.co/RuOpPOfOyt

"It's going to take us a long time to recover mentally and emotionally from this pandemic," @DavidWDowdy said.
